reviewText: This show is pure class. While season 5 had some disappointing moments here and there, I would rank every other season as pure, perfect comedic gold.  The show, for the most part, keeps getting better and better... it started airing about 13 years ago (there are huge gaps between the seasons, hence why it's only on season 8) and they've just continued to progress, impress, and evolve the show; how it delivers humor, how the stories link up, and what it all means. This is brilliant humor, but it's also daring humor.Some people miss Cheryl, some people don't like the new NY locales, some people aren't fans of the writing. But I honestly think this is the single all-around FUNNIEST season (and may end up being one of the best seasons overall when reflected upon later; it'll be hard to top season 3, though).  I am glad I didn't pay attention to the negative reviews. The show HAS changed but it's totally for the better.So yeah, get any Curb you can, but if you just want to see most of the funniest episodes, here you go.
summary: How does the best keep getting better?
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: I really think 'curb' is funny....of course, I'd never tolerate these people in my home, but it's fun to watch them from afar on your computer....I don't have TV, so it was fun to put 'curb' on while doing homework and stuff.  LarryDavid is annoying, but funny.  The first season sucks, so I would suggest the other seasons, they get better.

reviewText: Larry David is not for everybody, but he definitely makes me laugh.  I love watching him being as socially awkward as possible in everyday scenarios.  Great show

reviewerName: Author of Every Man Wants More Than One
reviewText: This has got to be one of TV's best original comedies.  Larry David is laugh-out-loud funny.  I will watch him in anything.

reviewText: For anyone that's a fan of the Seinfeld shows, "Curb Your Enthusiam" is a must see, however, I would recommend this t.v. series for anybody even if you've never saw a Seinfeld show.Larry David is a share genius. I don't know how he comes up with his ideas, but he is a true icon of the comedy world.I definitely highly recommend this extremely funny t.v. show series. After watching it, you'll hunger for more shows.I hope there will be another season. It's like you can't get enough of this show.Once you see one of his shows, you'll be hooked and want more and more.Bruce
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: I was a huge Seinfeld fan.  I never expected to like CURB as much.  I've watched every season and, if anything, it is better than Seinfeld. This is because with Larry there are no holds barred.  He is the whole comic all on his own who shines even brighter with a supporting cast but really needs no comic foil. I enjoyed Cheryl Hines when she was on playing his wife but Larry is more believable as a single guy.This season has so many funny moments that it would be an impossible task to recount them all. There is one where Larry's big thing becomes that he has to have a Jewish divorce lawyer. And he talks an LA team owner into doing the same.  So they both drop a top notch divorce lawyer and get a Jewish incompetent to represent them for predictable results. People really do silly things like this when choosing lawyers so it couldn't be any more spot on.Larry also has a superb feud with Michael J. Fox that is just brilliant.  Larry is rarely bested but here he is up against a disabled philanthropist who is slyly thinking up things by the moment to drive Larry crazy.  And does he ever!Larry's black roommate is, as always, hilarious.  The two of them together is always top flight.  There is one episode where they are mistakenly taken for a gay couple which is hilarious.  But they always end up together, whether in LA, NYC or even Paris! It's almost too bad they aren't gay as they are perfect for one another.Suzie is her foul mouthed best every time she appears onscreen.  jeff is his usual obnoxious self. Richard Lewis and Larry make their usual odd couple pairing as well.  They have been friends in real life since summer camp as kids but it is always a relationship in turmoil.  They wouldn't have it any other way either. This time Larry manages to convince Richard's new girlfriend to get a breast reduction operation when the main reason Richard likes her is because she has huge breasts!
summary: Larry Can Hold His Own; no Foil Needed
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: Season 8 is a vast improvement over the tepid Seinfeld reunion theme of the previous series.  In fact, this one is much more "pure Larry David"-- without the unnecessary embellishments and artifices that only detract from the basic humor that attracts intelligent viewers.  I do believe, however, that the recurring character, "Tessler", has outlived his usefulness.  In addition, there is a very real problem incorporating guest stars that don't really fit in with overall style of the show. In particular, the appearances of Ricky Gervais and Rosie O'Donnell come across as kind of awkward, forced and unnatural. Michael J. Fox, however, is much more natural and believable. The overall news is that the luster of the program has been restored and hopefully it will continue to shine in Season 9.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: Season 8 of Curb Your enthusiasum is Larry David's funniest season.  I found every episode a classic.  The writing, this season, is so acerbic, witty and just down right hilarious.  Larry is the catalyst to major catastrophes,and it always works.  What I find so funny, is that I always feel sorry for Larry, because he always begins something with good intentions.  I would strongly recommend getting this season's episodes, you will not be disappointed.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: This is more of season seven, season six, season five, season 4, season 2, and season 1.  But it's very different than season 3.  And I think season 3 was average.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: As a huge Seinfeld fan and later on a huge Curb fan, I think Larry David is a comical writing/story-telling genius. It also helps that he is such a funny and I dare say an iconic actor/comedian. I admit I was skeptical about ordering this dvd because I honestly didn't think the previous season (with the Seinfeld reunion) was that funny. I guess most all shows are bound to hit a lull and it seemed that is what happened with Curb. However, I just marathon-watched the first dvd of season 8 (there are 2 dvds- eps 1-7 on the first dvd and 8-10 I believe on the second) and each episode has been hilarious, causing me to laugh out loud at Larry's misfortunes. His manager Jeff is also incredibly funny as a supporting character, as is his friend Richard Lewis. These episodes remind me of the brilliance of the first few seasons when the show was absolutely the funniest show on television. I also kind of like his sidekick Leon but I could do without Leon's continuous use of profanity- every other syllable out of his mouth is the f-word. One problem that I have noticed with this dvd though is the audio track is off in several spots within some of the episodes. It's a little distracting but not too big a deal. The price of this dvd is pretty good- marked down from like $30 to $16. This season does not disappoint- the show is brilliant and Larry David is so funny. This is truly the show about nothing but it makes nothing so hilarious and real that you can't get enough of it- at least I can't...
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: I have a bias opinion on this simple because I LOVE THIS SHOW.  However, Season 8 brings it to another level.  AND it has some amazing cameos in it!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: Larry David is a comical genius, and I personally can't ever imagine this show getting old.  Not only is the material hilarious, but it also has a little dark humor to it.  Like Seinfeld, the whole show is pretty much about "nothing."  It's just about people getting wrapped up in silly, trivial issues every day, and is kind of a parody of life itself.  When asked where the title of the show came from, Larry's response was: "It reflects my perception that many people seem to live their lives projecting false enthusiasm, which I believes is used to imply that "they are better than you."Do I miss Cheryl?  Yes, I do.  I would have chosen to keep her in the cast, but her departure opened up a lot more opportunities to put Larry in hilarious and awkward situations with women.  And Larry is the same as he is with women as he is with everyone else - he acts just like Larry.  Leon is a great part of the cast - he's very "Krameresque" with his constant following of Larry wherever he goes and mooches off of him, but he says the most funny, silly, random things.I have all seven seasons so far, and can't wait to add this to my collection!  The replay value is great.  I go through them about once a year and I still laugh as hard as ever.  It's possible to watch these shows out of order and laugh, but there are enough life changes throughout the series (unlike Seinfeld) that make it more logical to watch it in order.There better be another season!
summary: "You know what you are? You're a social assassin." - Jeff
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: Great now I have all of the Curb Your Enthusiasm collections glad to now have the final DVD. The DVD shows well
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: you'll love season 8. LIke all the other seasons, it's about the quirkiest guy on earth and how maddening it must be to live his life. He's absolutely nuts. It's Seinfeld with cursing is as near as I can get to it.I own the entire Seinfeld and Curb series. This man is a genius.If you DON'T like Larry David, then you clearly won't like this series. It's that simple. While not the best season, which I think was season 2 or 3, this is certainly worth owning.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: I never thought I'd find a show funnier or as funny as Seinfeld, but Larry David's Curb Your Enthusiam is it. A mostly non-scripted show, set in the fictional life (with a lot of reality tossed in) of Larry David, it's simply hilarious. Not for kids under 13, but for adults, this is the way Seinfeld would have been had it been rated R. (I can also say it shows why Seinfeld wasn't as funny once Larry left). Get this and it will be watched many, many times. The best episodes involved Palestinian Chicken and Michael J. Fox, who is utterly hilarious. Give it a shot, you won't be disappointed!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: Cheryl has disappeared from Season 8, leaving Larry without a foil. There is no counter-Larry. This leaves an odd, gaping hole in the series. I loved seasons 1-7, but Larry without his usual buddies seems irrelevant. There's very little connecting one episode to the next in this season.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: Larry David, creator of "Steinfeld" is a rare genius. All these episodes, season after season, are hilarious and at the same time very subtle. Not everyone will get them. Maybe it's because these playful and intelligent comedies smack more of New York City and Los Angeles humor than they do America's heartland. Larry is always getting caught putting his foot in his mouth and that self deprecation makes the show.

Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: "Curb Your Enthusiasm" is part of a genre I like to call "painful comedy." It's incredibly funny; it's laugh out loud, laugh-until-you-almost-pass-out funny. But it is also very, very painful to watch. It takes the social awkwardness and comedy of errors that was Larry David's previous series, "Seinfeld," and cranks them up to the max.You can't help but sympathize with Larry and often some of the more innocent bystanders that exist in his world. The situations he's constantly finding himself in are hysterical, but you have to cringe in-between laughing. I often watch this with family and we find that we have to "take breaks" very often. While we have been known to watch "Seinfeld" on a regular basis for months on end, we're more likely to only watch "Curb Your Enthusiasm" once every few months as it is, frankly, emotionally exhausting, if you watch with any amount of emotional investment.Season Eight continues the same level of high-quality writing and improv seen in all the earlier seasons. In this particular story arc, Larry travels to New York, which is an interesting creative choice, as it puts Larry back on his home turf (both the fictionalized Larry of the show and the real Larry). Michael J. Fox has a guest appearance, and it's wonderful guest spot indeed (and yes, Parkinson's Disease forms the basis of a joke and yes, it is funny). Thankfully, too, Larry's long-time roommate Leon, played to perfection by J.B. Smoove, is along for the trip to New York City. Leon is my favorite character on the show, and I hope he remains as a major part of the cast for the rest of the series' run (and heck, why doesn't Smoove have his own show yet?).The DVD set comes in the same form it has before for pretty much every other season. Special features includes "Leon's Guide to NYC," which is maybe not as funny as J.B. Smoove's usual work (perhaps because he doesn't have any other actors or situations to play off of) but still good for a chuckle, and a really fascinating discussion of the show with the main cast (Jeff's comments comparing the appeal of "Curb Your Enthusiasm" to Pixar films was especially enlightening and memorable).The improv-style performances of the show continue to prove that with the right actors and outline writers, a script isn't even necessary. If you're a fan of "Seinfeld" or previous seasons of the show, then I think you're going to love this DVD set.It's pretty good. Pretty, pretty, pretty good.
summary: You'll Laugh, You'll Cry, You'll Cry Cry Again
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: Loved the entire series.  It is mostly crazy - Larry's view of his world keeps you smiling.  A person who says what he thinks - Larry David hits the 'nail on the head' most of the time.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: Larry David is a comedic genius. Season 8 is a great addition to the Curb series but I don't think it's the best season. Some episodes had me in stitches (i.e. The Vow of Silence) while others had a resounding whomp whomp (i.e. Palestinian Chicken). But even with the boring episodes Curb remains one of the funniest shows on television.I won't pretend that this is everyone's sense of humor but if you enjoy shows like Seinfeld then you can't go wrong. I wouldn't start with season 8 if you haven't forayed into Curb before, start with season 3 and work your way up.
summary: Is it the best season of Curb? No. But is it awesome? Yes!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: The season starts very strong with an episode about his divorce from Sheryl who then disappears from the show. After this there is a great number of great shows that poke fun of the usual things: judaism, disabled people but with somewhat more aggression than usual. Now, it is brilliant do not get me wrong here but the Larry David we see here is somewhat more bitter if not funnier than before. There is a somewhat lame mid-season episode but  it all ends on a very very strong  note. While it may not be his consistently best season, due to a few duds, it does contain some of his best bits ever. Indeed, since in order not too offend people too uch, Larry david ends up moving to New York and from there of course chaos ensues. There are some great guest performances such as the one by Micheal J Fox as himself in an incredible episode about Parkinsonism that has to be seen to be believed. You cannot go wrong by  buying this season. He does not seem to get weaker at all and this is season 8.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: This show makes me laugh out loud. Larry David is so funny and keeps totally in character. I love this grumpy old man. Really like to hate him but at same time can sympathize with his plight.

Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: I did not set my expectations as high for Season 8 because I was not satisfied with Season 7. However, I was pleasantly surprised. Although this is not the greatest season, it is not the worst either. It is an average season. When Curb has been as good as it has been at times, this season may not seem like enough for some people. Yet overall it is above average Curb and shows Larry David could keep this going if he wanted to.Season 8 is a mixture of old and new Curb in that there are some familiar routines repeated in different settings and production techniques have been tightened up, this time successfully in most cases. Larry David's maxim, "If it is scripted it isn't funny" proved itself out in Season 7's completely fake Seinfeld reunion rehearsals with the crew laughing as the cast read the script. I also thought this proved to be true when Larry did the Mel Brooks Broadway play with all of the shots of people laughing in an earlier season. It is not merely shots of people faking a laugh it is the serious attempt at making something appear funny that isn't. Both cases didn't warrant laughs and went against the grain of LD's adage.In the beginning Curb was filmed with most actors on camera having just a hint of the topic and left to react naturally to what unfolded. Scenes often involved everyone delivering their lines in one continuous shot. In later seasons LD has relied more on written dialog and editing with each actor delivering separately filmed lines. Until this season the editing had been awkward. It seemed to start as a band-aid revealing the flubs and discomfort that prompted the need to abandon the spontaneity of the earlier approach. In Season 8 this has been successfully tightened up. Perhaps they changed the objective. Use separate takes to build a good scene rather than to repair bad takes. Many scenes work and best of all they are funny most of the time as well.Jeff Garlin has always been one of the regulars who appears comfortable and manages to be funny under Curb's spontaneous style. Fortunately he is back and included in every episode. J.D. Smoove (Leon Black) has been a great addition as a regular and he follows Larry through the last episode this season. There is very little of Cheryl Hines and Richard Lewis (he has never been more enjoyable than in Curb, IMO). Oddly, Curb veteran Susie Essman is one of the most awkward with the Curb style this season. Missing is Ted Danson another who has been very good. Jeff, Cheryl and Larry have not aged a day since the series began.With a few minor caveats Season 8 is a good season, not the greatest and not the worst.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: This season was the funniest so far. Larry relocates to New York and it is good to see him on his home turf. Guest appearance by  Robert Smigal (the voice of Triumph the insult comic dog) is the best. Bill Buckner is equally as funny in this episode.

reviewText: I couldn't agree more with the reviewer AKW. There is quote on the back cover of the DVD from a professional reviewer that the 8th is the best season ever. It is not. Unfortunately is the worst (I am sorry to say that, but it is the truth). But Larry even on his worst moments is better than everybody else. So I think it is still worth watching.Dialogues were contrived. I didn't sense spontaneity. Larry was too on the edge, forceful, losing the surprise element. I hope that Curb is not getting old. He tried a change and I commend him for that. The problem is that the end result is not as funny. Maybe the problem was on the execution. I am not sure.The best episode is the "Palestinian Restaurant". That's the episode that the season will remembered for. But even on this one I felt that it was a missed opportunity.The episode with Ricky Gervais had its moments, the one with Michael J. Fox was mostly flat.The DVD extra has a 90 minutes quite funny conversation with the cast and Brian Williams. Larry said that he lost his Blackberry and all his notes that was saved in the device. I wonder if it was the notes for this season.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: It is without reservation that I share my endless "uncurbed" enthusiasm for this series, which is easily one of the best on TV.  I own the DVDs from all seasons, and usually can't wait to acquire the next one. I watch them over and over and am never bored.  The brilliant improvisational acting, as well as the hilarious humor and fabulous ideas for every episode are of the highest calibre. I highly recommend every season of "Curb your enthusiasm".
summary: As always, one of the BEST on TV!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: I've enjoyed every season of this hilarious show, which is largely non-scripted. This one may not be as solidly funny as previous seasons, but you'll have many laughs, nonetheless. I recommend it if you're a Larry David fan--he is a comic genius, IMO.

reviewText: Cheryl's a great character, but she really doesn't make or break the show. This season was incredible. No drop in quality whatsoever. If this is the last season, as much as I want more, I'd be satisfied with it ending this way.

Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: "Curb Your Enthusiasm: The Complete Eighth Season" finds Larry David traveling to New York City, where he confronts, among others, new girlfriends, the Girl Scouts, politicians, and Michael J. Fox.  David's humor often makes you wince and then laugh hysterically.The show blurs the line between reality and fiction and the scripts consist only of scene outlines, giving it a fresh and spontaneous narrative and improvisational quality.  Jeff Garlin plays Larry's friend and manager, but it's Susie Essman as Jeff's wife who steals every scene she's in with her hilarious, X-rated tirades against Larry or anyone else who crosses her.Available on Blu-ray and DVD, the set offers bonus features including a roundtable discussion with Larry David and cast.
summary: Larry Makes You Squirm, Then Laugh
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 8

reviewText: This is one of the best comedy TV shows ever! If you've given up on sit-com TV in the past due to horrible laugh tracks....then come on back to real genius comedy with CURB!
summary: SHEER GENIUS and best of all NO FRIKIN' LAUGH TRACK - Thank you Larry David!

reviewText: I have been a devoted fan of "Friends" and  "Curb your Enthusiasm" w/Larry David himself.This particular season is not as good as the others. I believe that (almost) "killing" off the Cheryl Hines character, his wife on the show, has diminished the humourous situations.Suzie and Wanda continue being great additions, and of course great best pal Jeff, Richard, etc. A great cast, and worth watching, but I miss Cheryl.Th Eighth Season was not as funny or engaging.
